content.zh:
我们探讨过“homo sacer”这个词的译法问题。对于阿甘本的著作，中文译本可以找到“神圣人”和“牲人”两种用语。

在推送发出后，我们的好友安太然补充提醒我们，拉丁语中的sacer本就是一个典型的“contronym”（反训词），兼有“神圣的、不可触碰的”和“臭名昭著的、被诅咒的”两重意思。可能这也是为什么“homo sacer”一词的译法存在如此多有趣的争议。

我们借上这个由头，今天的推送就简单介绍“反训词”，并捎带上“反义复词”这个概念。当然，“反义复词”一般用在汉语的分析当中，英文中的相关词语是我们个人延伸出的，将它们称作“反义混成词”应该更为恰当。
content.en:
We previously explored the translation of the term homo sacer. In the Chinese editions of Giorgio Agamben’s works, two distinct renderings can be found: Shengsheng Ren (Sacred Man) and Sheng Ren (The Expendable/Sacrificial Man).
Following our previous post, our friend An Tairan added a insightful reminder that the Latin word sacer is itself a quintessential contronym. It encompasses the dual meanings of "sacred/inviolable" and "infamous/accursed." This inherent ambiguity likely explains why the translation of homo sacer remains a subject of such intriguing debate.
Taking this as a starting point, today’s post will briefly introduce the concept of contronyms, along with the notion of antonymous compounds. While the latter is typically used in the analysis of the Chinese language, we have personally extended this logic to English. It would perhaps be more appropriate to refer to these English equivalents as antonymous portmanteaus.

content.zh: 有几个成语是我在搜索反训词的相关知识的时候联想到的，几个好友也有补充：“差强人意”，原本的意思是“大体上能够让人满意”，但经常被误用为相反的意思。“万人空巷”，原本指的是人挤人的热闹盛况，很多时候被误用作相反的意思，“街上没人”。最好笑的应该是“空穴来风”，自相矛盾的两个意思已经写在现代汉语词典里了：原本比喻“传言有所依据”，现在用来指“传言没有依据”。这些词再这样用下去，可能已经起不到交流的作用了…
content.en:
While researching contronyms, several Chinese idioms came to mind—some also suggested by friends. For instance, cha qiang ren yi (差强人意) originally meant "largely satisfactory," yet it is frequently misused to convey the exact opposite. Then there is wan ren kong xiang (万人空巷), which describes a bustling scene where everyone has poured out of their homes to throng the streets; ironically, it is often misinterpreted to mean "empty streets with no one in sight."
Perhaps the most amusing case is kong xue lai feng (空穴来风). The two contradictory meanings are now both officially recorded in modern Chinese dictionaries: while it originally alluded to "rumors having a factual basis," it is now commonly used to mean "rumors with no basis at all." If we continue to use these words in such a manner, they may eventually lose their function as a medium for communication altogether...

content.zh: 不知道算不算反训词相关现象，不过 fact 来自 拉丁文 factum 意思是「人做的一件事或者制作的一个东西」，后面衍生出事实（fact）和虚假（factitious）这两个方向的含义
content.en: I am not certain if this strictly qualifies as a contronym-related phenomenon, but the word fact originates from the Latin factum, meaning "a thing done" or "a thing made." Interestingly, it evolved into two divergent semantic directions: fact, representing objective reality, and factitious, which denotes something artificial or false.

brief_definition.zh: 一对单音反义词结合起来构成的一个新词
brief_definition.en: A word formed by the combination of a pair of monosyllabic antonyms

zh: 中文里有很多由相反意思汉字组成的两字词，比如“多少”、“好歹”、“褒贬”、“沉浮”、“巨细”、“天地”等。
这些词中很多是偏义复词，即偏重这两个意思中的其中一个：比如“谁主沉浮”，偏向浮，“不计得失”，偏重失。有些词以相反的两个点为基础，指的是这之间的整个事物，比如“天地”。也有一些用来比喻或者提喻其他事物，比如用“手足”指代兄弟，“开关”提喻电子器械的点按装置。
英文中的合成词（compound）或混成词（blend words）中也有一些是由意义相反的词直接组合而成的。比如“bittersweet”（bitter+sweet，悲喜交集），口语上说的“frenemy”（friend+enemy，亦敌亦友）。这些词的含义就是两个组成部分的混合。
不过也有一些历史更古老的词也是由两个相反的词拼成，但带有其组成部分之外的含义。比如“sophomore”这个词，意思则是“大学二年级的学生”。
en: The Chinese language contains many disyllabic words composed of antonymic characters, such as "much and little" (duōshǎo 多少), "good and bad" (hǎodài 好歹), "praise and criticism" (bàobiǎn 褒贬), "rise and fall" (chénfú 沉浮), "magnitude" (jùxì 巨细), and "heaven and earth" (tiāndì 天地).

Many of these are partial-meaning compounds (偏义复词), where the emphasis is placed on only one of the two components. For instance, in the phrase "Who governs the rise and fall" (谁主沉浮), the weight is on "rise" (fú 浮); in "regardless of gain or loss" (不计得失), the focus is on "loss" (shī 失).

Other terms use two opposing poles to represent an entire spectrum, such as "heaven and earth" (天地) denoting the universe. Some function as metaphors or synecdoches (提喻), such as using "hands and feet" (手足) to refer to brothers, or "on and off" (开关) as a synecdoche for the toggling mechanism of electronic devices.

Similar constructions exist in English through compound words or blends. We see this in "bittersweet" (a fusion of bitter and sweet) and the colloquial "frenemy" (friend and enemy), where the meaning is a direct blend of both parts.

However, some etymologically ancient words are also composed of opposites but carry a significance beyond their literal parts. A prime example is "sophomore" (a second-year student), which originates from the Greek roots sophos ("wise") and moros ("foolish")—rendering the literal but hidden meaning of a "wise fool."

example_sentence.zh: 中文中的反义复词和英文中的矛盾结合词（Oxymoronic Compound）既有共性又有差异，比如英文词sophomore（大学二年级学生）是后者的一个例子，它由希腊词根sophistēs（智慧、有经验的人）和mōros（傻子、白痴）混成；oximoron（矛盾修辞法）这个词本身也是一个例子，它由希腊语中的oxys（锐利的）和mōros（愚钝的）组成。
example_sentence.en: Antonymous compounds (fǎnyì fùcí 反义复词) in Chinese and oxymoronic compounds in English share both commonalities and distinct differences. For instance, the English word sophomore (a second-year college student) is a classic example of the latter; it is a blend of the Greek roots sophos (wise or experienced) and mōros (foolish or idiotic). The term oxymoron (a figure of speech that pairs contradictory terms) is itself another example, derived from the Greek words oxys (sharp/keen) and mōros (dull/stupid).

brief_definition.zh: 与外界没有因果联系的时空区域的边界面，常见于黑洞的表面
brief_definition.en: The boundary interface of a spacetime region that has no causal connection with the outside world is commonly found on the surface of a black hole.

zh: 想象一下，你正坐在一艘飞船里，不幸被一个巨大黑洞的引力捕获，正无可挽回地滑向它的中心。起初，你还能看到飞船仪表盘的光亮，也能看到远处未被黑洞吞噬的星光。但随着你越来越接近那个神秘的中心点，奇怪的事情发生了：你回头望向飞船的舷窗，试图看到你来的方向，却发现外面的星光似乎被拉长、扭曲，然后……消失了。你并非坠入了黑暗，而是到达了一个连光都无法向外逃逸的边界——事件视界。在这个边界之内，任何信息，包括你发出的求救信号、飞船引擎的亮光，甚至是你最后的一声叹息，都将永远无法被边界之外的宇宙所知晓。你与外部宇宙的因果联系，被彻底切断了。

在爱因斯坦的广义相对论中，物质和能量会使时空结构发生弯曲。当这种弯曲达到极致，比如在黑洞周围，就会形成一个特殊的边界——事件视界。它标志着时空中的一个临界点：在这个边界之内（朝向黑洞中心的方向），时空的弯曲是如此剧烈，以至于任何物体（包括以光速运动的光子）的未来路径都只能指向黑洞的中心奇点，而无法再折返或逃逸到边界之外。因此，视界内部发生的一切事件（如飞船解体、时间流逝），都无法以任何形式（信号、光线、引力波）影响到视界之外的外部宇宙。反之，外部宇宙也无法直接影响视界内部。它就像一个单向膜，只允许物质和信息进入，但禁止其逃出。虽然事件视界最常见于黑洞表面（被称为史瓦西半径），但理论上也可能存在于其他极端引力环境（如某些宇宙模型中的宇宙视界）。2019年，事件视界望远镜（EHT）合作项目发布的首张黑洞（M87星系中心）照片，其模糊光环的中心暗影区域，就大致对应着该黑洞事件视界的投影，让这个深奥的理论概念首次拥有了直观的视觉证据。
en: Imagine that you are sitting in a spaceship, unfortunately caught by the gravitational pull of a massive black hole and sliding inexorably towards its center. At first, you can still see the light on the spaceship's dashboard and the distant stars that haven't been devoured by the black hole. But as you get closer and closer to that mysterious center point, strange things happen: you look back at the spaceship's window, trying to see the direction you came from, but you find that the outside stars seem to be stretched, distorted, and then... disappear. You are not falling into darkness, but reaching a boundary where even light cannot escape - the event horizon. Within this boundary, any information, including your distress signals, the light from the spaceship's engine, and even your last sigh, will never be known by the universe beyond the boundary. Your causal connection with the external universe is completely severed.

In Einstein's general theory of relativity, matter and energy cause the structure of spacetime to bend. When this bending reaches its extreme, such as around a black hole, a special boundary is formed - the event horizon. It marks a critical point in spacetime: within this boundary (towards the center of the black hole), the curvature of spacetime is so intense that the future path of any object (including photons moving at the speed of light) can only point towards the black hole's central singularity, and cannot return or escape beyond the boundary. Therefore, all events that occur within the event horizon (such as the disintegration of the spaceship, the passage of time) cannot affect the external universe beyond the boundary in any form (signals, light, gravitational waves). Conversely, the external universe cannot directly affect the interior of the event horizon. It is like a one-way membrane that only allows matter and information to enter but prohibits their escape. Although the event horizon is most commonly found on the surface of a black hole (known as the Schwarzschild radius), theoretically it can also exist in other extreme gravitational environments (such as the cosmic horizon in certain universe models). In 2019, the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) collaboration project released the first image of a black hole (at the center of the M87 galaxy), with the dark shadow at the center of the blurry ring, roughly corresponding to the projection of this black hole's event horizon, giving this profound theoretical concept its first visual evidence.

example_sentence.zh: 在构思硬核科幻小说时，作者需要精确理解事件视界的物理含义：任何落入其中的角色或飞船，从宇宙的视角看，其命运在穿过边界的那一刻就已注定与外部世界彻底隔绝，任何信息都无法逃逸出来。

brief_definition.zh: 指源自潜意识层面的，由于压抑某些冲动和意图造成的，在言语、记忆或肢体动作上出现的失误行为
brief_definition.en: It refers to the mistakes in speech, memory or body movements that arise from the subconscious level due to the suppression of certain impulses and intentions.

zh: 想象一下，你正在参加一场重要的面试，面试官问起你的职业规划时，你本想自信地说“我渴望成为团队领导者”，却脱口而出“我害怕成为团队领导者”。这种看似简单的口误，在精神分析学中被称为“行为倒错”。它不只是日常的失误，而是潜意识中压抑的冲动或焦虑的短暂暴露。
弗洛伊德派理论认为，行为倒错源于本我（id）对自我（ego）的边界突破。当个体在道德或社会规范的压力下，压抑与性、暴力或创伤相关的欲望时，这些冲动会退入潜意识。但如果压抑不够牢固，它们就可能以口误、笔误、误听或暂时性遗忘的形式“泄露”出来。例如，在厨房做菜时叫错女友名字，可能暗示了未解决的过去情感。
英文术语“Parapraxis”源自希腊语前缀“Para”（意为“另一个”）和“Praxis”（意为“行动”），强调这是一种“替代性行为”。它与梦的机制相似，都是潜意识通过伪装方式表达真实意图。弗洛伊德在1901年的著作中，将这类现象视为通往潜意识的重要窗口，帮助我们理解人类心理的复杂性。行为倒错提醒我们，日常错误往往承载着深层心理冲突，而非单纯的疏忽。
en: Imagine that you are attending an important interview. When the interviewer asks about your career plan, you were about to confidently say "I aspire to be a team leader", but instead you blurted out "I'm afraid of being a team leader". This seemingly simple slip of the tongue is called "behavioral inversion" in psychoanalysis. It is not just a common mistake, but a brief exposure of repressed impulses or anxiety in the subconscious.

The Freudian theory holds that behavioral distortion stems from the boundary breach of the id (the primitive part of the psyche) over the ego. When an individual is under the pressure of moral or social norms and suppresses desires related to sex, violence, or trauma, these impulses retreat into the subconscious. However, if the suppression is not strong enough, they may "leak" out in the form of slips of the tongue, writing errors, mishearing, or temporary forgetfulness. For instance, calling one's girlfriend's name wrongly while cooking in the kitchen might imply unresolved past emotions.

The English term "Parapraxis" is derived from the Greek prefix "Para" (meaning "another") and "Praxis" (meaning "action"), emphasizing that it is a "substitute behavior". It is similar to the mechanism of dreams, both of which are ways for the subconscious to express true intentions through disguise. In his 1901 work, Freud regarded such phenomena as an important window to the subconscious, helping us understand the complexity of human psychology. Parapraxis reminds us that everyday mistakes often carry deep psychological conflicts rather than being simple negligence.

brief_definition.zh: 新社会结构下的阶层概念，指从生产者社会走向消费者社会后，有缺陷的消费者
brief_definition.en: The concept of social classes in the new social structure refers to the flawed consumers who emerge after the transition from a producer-based society to a consumer-based society.

zh: 想象一下，一个名叫小张的年轻人，刚毕业就进入一家科技公司工作。他每月工资勉强够付房租和基本开销，但看到同事们都在炫耀新款的智能手机和周末的豪华旅行时，他感到一种无形的压力。一次公司聚餐，大家讨论着最新上市的电动汽车，小张只能默默低头——他连首付都凑不齐。这种无法参与“正常”消费的羞愧感，让他觉得自己像个局外人，尽管他勤奋工作，却总被贴上“不够成功”的标签。这就是“新穷人”的典型处境：在消费者社会中，他们不是饿肚子的人，而是消费能力不足的“缺陷者”。

这个概念源于社会结构的深刻转变。在工业革命时期的生产者社会里，工作伦理主导一切：人们被教育要勤劳、忠诚，像机器一样运转，不工作被视为道德败坏。穷人往往是那些“懒惰”或“散漫”的工人，社会用“有付出才有收获”的信念来驱使他们。但随着经济全球化，社会进化到消费者社会——这里，身份和阶级不再由工作能力定义，而是由消费选择自由决定。我们一生都在被训练成消费者：从广告到社交媒体，都在暗示“体面生活”的标准是买得起房、开好车、追潮流。新穷人就是那些无法达到这些标准的人，他们可能有一份工作，却因高物价、低工资或失业而消费受限。贫穷不再是生存威胁（如饥饿），而是一种社会心理排斥：无法消费意味着被边缘化，引发羞愧和负罪感。全球范围内，这种“新贫穷”在发达城市尤为明显，它提醒我们，消费主义如何重塑了不平等。
en: Imagine a young man named Xiao Zhang who just graduated and started working at a technology company. His monthly salary was barely enough to cover rent and basic expenses. But when he saw his colleagues showing off their new smartphones and enjoying luxurious weekend trips, he felt an invisible pressure. At a company dinner, everyone was discussing the newly launched electric vehicles. Xiao Zhang could only lower his head in silence - he couldn't even come up with the down payment. This shame of being unable to participate in "normal" consumption made him feel like an outsider, despite his hard work, he was always labeled as "not successful enough". This is the typical situation of the "new poor": in a consumer society, they are not the starving ones, but the "defective" ones with insufficient consumption capacity.

This concept stems from the profound transformation of social structure. In the producer society during the Industrial Revolution, work ethics dominated everything: people were educated to be diligent and loyal, to operate like machines, and not working was regarded as moral corruption. The poor were often those "lazy" or "disorganized" workers, and society used the belief that "paying the price leads to rewards" to drive them. However, with economic globalization, society has evolved into a consumer society - here, identity and class are no longer defined by work ability, but by the freedom of consumption choices. We are all being trained to be consumers throughout our lives: from advertisements to social media, they all imply that the standard of a "decent life" is to be able to afford a house, drive a good car, and follow the trends. The new poor are those who cannot meet these standards; they may have a job, but due to high prices, low wages, or unemployment, their consumption is limited. Poverty is no longer a threat to survival (such as hunger), but a social psychological exclusion: being unable to consume means being marginalized, which triggers shame and guilt. Globally, this "new poverty" is particularly evident in developed cities, reminding us how consumerism has reshaped inequality.

作为词条作者回复一层朋友的问题（我写的太长了最后一个发不出去😁）首先新穷人是一个系统现象/问题，我认为个人解决的第一步是在自己的日常生活中思考这个现象。如果可以为其发声，可以避免消费主义被无限地合理化。

brief_definition.zh: 一种生活状态，指人们频繁移动，进行高强度劳动，暂停常规生活，以便快速获益然后迅速逃离
brief_definition.en: A state of life, characterized by frequent movement, intense labor, and suspension of regular life, in order to quickly gain benefits and then quickly escape.

zh: 想象一个年轻的程序员，他从北京搬到深圳，再辗转上海，像一只永不停歇的蜂鸟，在每个城市只停留几个月。白天，他接单做自由职业项目，晚上挤在合租屋里刷招聘网站，只为攒够一笔钱就“逃离”回老家创业。这种生活不是扎根，而是悬在半空——高强度劳动换来短暂收益，却暂停了结婚、买房或社区融入的常规轨迹。

“悬浮”一词，由人类学家项飙提出，描述了现代社会中个体的一种普遍存在状态：人们频繁迁移，进行高强度劳动（如零工经济中的外卖骑手或程序员），主动暂停常规生活（如家庭或社区归属），目的是快速积累财富后迅速“逃离”。这类似于蜂鸟振翅悬停的形象：努力前进却无法着陆，既不批判性参与当下，也不完全脱离。项飙认为，这种状态是发展主义（developmentalism）的缩影——先追求经济收益，问题留待未来解决。它反映了行动者的能动性：一种模糊而脆弱的希望，常被社会结构（如城乡二元制）压制，导致人们反复追问“为什么别无选择？”
在全球零工经济兴起背景下，“悬浮”已成为中国高速发展的隐形引擎。大量农民工或城市白领通过这种状态支撑了服务型经济转型，但也加剧了不平等和环境问题。它像一把双刃剑：短期内维持社会稳定（通过听天由命与希望的混合），长期却可能消解而非解决问题，正如四十年的疯狂发展所暴露的挑战。如今，随着“悬浮”常态化和信念动摇，这个概念正成为社会批判的透镜，揭示行动者在霸权压制下的韧性。
en: Imagine a young programmer who moved from Beijing to Shenzhen, then to Shanghai, like a never-stopping hummingbird, staying in each city for only a few months. During the day, he took on freelance projects, and at night, he crowded in a shared apartment to browse recruitment websites, all in an effort to save enough money to "escape" back to his hometown to start a business. This kind of life is not rooted; it is suspended in mid-air - intense labor yields short-term gains, but it halts the regular trajectory of getting married, buying a house, or integrating into the community.

“悬浮”这个不算新鲜，跟小蓝交流的时候她也表示这些词，包括内卷、躺平、异化什么的，都被“用到包浆”了。但自从共创会上听小蓝比较成系统地讲了之后，我还是很经常回味“悬浮”这个词的意味，并且产生很多发散的联想。一是它似乎可以被看做是“栖居”的反面：欧洲中世纪人把此世搁置起来，作为赎罪，把幸福美好寄托到来世。对于当代中国语境，那么主教们总对高三学生说：现在辛苦一年，高考完就自由了轻松了。但事实上从小学一年级开始，每一年都被讲作“最关键的一年”，耽误不得，于是一个人不断搁置当下，不断对着先苦后甜的说法充饥。这可能也是一种“悬浮”？另有一种成年人的常见自我pua，自我画饼：“等我xx了我就xx”，最后始终没有充分地活在当下

brief_definition.zh: 通过当下涉海行为而非亲属血缘定义的流动身份
brief_definition.en: A fluid identity defined by immediate sea-related actions rather than kinship or descent.

zh: 想象你站在马达加斯加西海岸的沙滩上，看着两个人在海边劳作。其中一人皮肤黝黑、手掌粗茧，但他正弯着腰在小片旱地上拨弄庄稼；另一人则是刚从独木舟上跳下、全身湿透、正熟练地解开缠绕在指缝间的鱼线。对于当地人来说，那一刻，只有后者是“维佐人”，而前者——即便他父母都是维佐人——此时此刻也被视为“内陆人”。

这就是维佐人独特的身份观：身份不是一种“存在状态”（State of being），而是一种“行为方式”（Way of doing）。要被认可为维佐人，不需要查验你的族谱或DNA，只需要观察你当下的行动。如果你像维佐人一样栖海而居、乘风破浪、捕鱼为生，你就是维佐人。这种身份具有极强的“实时性”：一个孩子在学会游泳前只能被称为“小维佐”；一个维佐人如果搬到内陆种地，他在握住锄头的那一刻就不再是维佐人。身份就像是刻在身体上的动态纹章——指尖被鱼线勒出的深痕、为了抓牢沙地而形成的独特步态，都是“做”出来的证明。这种彻底的“获致身份”告诉我们，人不是由他的过去决定的，而是由他正在创造的当下决定的。
en: Imagine standing on the sun-drenched shores of western Madagascar, watching two people at work. One has dark skin and calloused hands but is bent over a small plot of dry land tending to crops; the other has just leapt from an outrigger canoe, dripping wet, skillfully untangling a fishing line caught between his fingers. To the locals, at that exact moment, only the latter is "Vezo," while the former—even if both his parents were born Vezo—is considered an "inlander."

This is the essence of Vezo identity: it is not a "state of being" but a "way of doing." To be recognized as Vezo, one does not need to produce a genealogy or a DNA test; one only needs to be observed in action. If you live by the sea, navigate the waves, and sustain yourself through fishing, you are Vezo. This identity is intensely "real-time": a child is merely a "little Vezo" until they master swimming; a Vezo person who moves inland to farm ceases to be Vezo the moment they grip a hoe. Identity is like a dynamic crest etched upon the body—the deep scars on fingertips from fishing lines and the distinctive gait adapted for gripping sand are all "performed" proofs. This radical "achieved status" suggests that a person is defined not by their past, but by the present they are actively creating.

example_sentence.zh: 在维佐人的哲学里，并没有“一劳永逸”的归属感；这提醒了每一个在大城市里感到迷失的现代人：定义我们的不应是那张薄薄的出生证明，而应是我们每天坚持在做的事情。
example_sentence.en: In Vezo philosophy, there is no such thing as a "once and for all" sense of belonging; this serves as a reminder to every lost soul in the modern metropolis that we are defined not by a birth certificate, but by what we choose to do every day.

brief_definition.zh: 源自同一原始语种并由共同词根演变而来的亲属词汇
brief_definition.en: Kin terms derived from the same proto-language and evolved from a common root

zh: 在一个晴朗的夜晚仰望星空。 如果你身处英国，你会指着那闪烁的光点说 "Star"； 如果你跨过海峡来到德国，当地人会称之为 "Stern"； 如果你穿越时空回到古罗马，你会听到 "Stella"； 如果你再去到古希腊，那里的人们叫它 "Aster"。
这些词为何这样相似？这是因为它们拥有同一个“祖母”——原始印欧语（Proto-Indo-European）中的 h₂stḗr。
这就是“同源词”（Cognates）。它的词源来自拉丁语 cognatus，意为“血脉相连”或“一起出生”。 同源词就像是一个庞大氏族中分散在各地的堂兄弟。几千年前，由于部落迁徙，同一个语言家族分家了。随着时间的推移，原本相同的一个词，在不同的地理环境和发音习惯下，各自演变成了不同的模样，但它们的核心基因（词义和基本音架）依然保留着相似性。
值得注意的是，同源词和外来词（Loanwords）是不同的。比如英语中管寿司叫做Sushi，但这是直接从日语借来的，所以英语和日语中的sushi，两者并不是同源词。
en: Gaze up at the starry sky on a clear night. If you were in Britain, you would point to those twinkling dots and say "Star"; if you crossed the channel to Germany, the locals would call them "Stern"; if you traveled through time to ancient Rome, you would hear "Stella"; and if you visited ancient Greece, the people there would call them "Aster."
Why are these words so similar? It is because they share the same "grandmother"—the Proto-Indo-European (PIE) root h₂stḗr.

These are what we call "Cognates." The term originates from the Latin cognatus, meaning "connected by blood" or "born together." Cognates are like cousins of a vast clan scattered across different lands. Thousands of years ago, due to tribal migrations, a single language family branched out. Over time, the same original word evolved into distinct forms under different geographic environments and phonetic habits; yet, their core genes—their meaning and basic phonetic framework—remain strikingly similar.

It is worth noting that cognates are distinct from loanwords. For instance, the English word for sushi is "sushi," but this was borrowed directly from Japanese. Therefore, "sushi" in English and "sushi" in Japanese are not cognates.

brief_definition.zh: 源自同一语源但因演变路径不同而产生形态差异的词汇对
brief_definition.en: A pair of words derived from the same etymological source but possessing morphological differences due to divergent evolutionary paths.

zh: 同源异形词就像是在婴儿时期就失散的双胞胎兄弟。哥哥留在了家乡，在原初的环境中长大；弟弟则被送到了国外，经历了一番锤炼后回乡。多年后，当弟弟与哥哥重逢时，尽管他们的基因（词根）完全相同，但外貌、口音和气质（拼写、读音和含义）已经截然不同。
最经典的例子莫过于英语中的 Shirt（衬衫）和 Skirt（裙子）。它们都源自原始日耳曼语的 skurtaz（短衣服）。哥哥 Shirt 是土生土长的古英语词，一直留在英语中演变；而弟弟 Skirt 则随维京人去了北欧，演变为古诺斯语，后来又随着维京人的入侵“回”到了英语中。于是，同一个词根分化成了两个词，分别指代了男人的上衣和女人的下装。

造成这种现象的原因通常是时间和路径的差异。比如Frail 和 Fragile 都来自拉丁语中的Fragilis，但前者已经失掉了原本的“g”，后者却比较完好地保留了原拉丁语词的发音和拼写。 这是因为“哥哥”Frail（脆弱的）离开拉丁语很久了，大约在13-14世纪就通过古法语进入了英语。在漫长的中世纪，原本的辅音 "g" 在几百年的口耳相传中被“磨”掉了； 而“弟弟”Fragile（易碎的），则是后来（约15-17世纪）直接从拉丁语或通过学术著作被“请”回英语的。这种“书面借词”或“学究借词”，较为完好地保留了拉丁语父亲的基因。
en: Doublets are like twin brothers separated in infancy. The elder brother remains at home, growing up in his ancestral environment, while the younger is sent abroad, returning only after a long period of refinement and trial. Years later, when they reunite, despite sharing identical genes (roots), their appearance, accent, and temperament (spelling, pronunciation, and meaning) have become worlds apart.

The most classic example is the pair "Shirt" and "Skirt." Both originate from the Proto-Germanic skurtaz (meaning "short garment"). The elder brother, "Shirt," is a native Old English word that evolved within the language. The younger, "Skirt," traveled to Scandinavia with the Vikings, evolved into Old Norse, and eventually "returned" to English following the Viking invasions. Consequently, the same root diverged into two distinct words, eventually designating a man's upper garment and a woman's lower garment, respectively.

The causes of this phenomenon are typically differences in time and trajectory. For instance, "Frail" and "Fragile" both derive from the Latin fragilis. However, the former has lost its original "g," while the latter preserves the Latin spelling and pronunciation quite well. This is because the "elder brother," "Frail," left Latin centuries ago, entering English via Old French around the 13th or 14th century. Throughout the long Middle Ages, the original consonant "g" was "eroded" through centuries of oral transmission. In contrast, the "younger brother," "Fragile," was "invited" back into English later (around the 15th to 17th century) directly from Latin or through scholarly texts. Such "learned borrowings" or "bookish loanwords" tend to preserve the genes of their Latin father much more intact.

brief_definition.en: A form of translation in which a foreign word is translated part-by-part according to its literal meaning and reassembled based on its original morphological principles

zh: 中文里的“蓝牙”一词译自英文中的“blue-tooth”。“摩天大楼”一词译自“skyscraper”。这些都是典型的“仿译词”。“Blue”是蓝色，“tooth”是牙齿，这个英文单词被拆为两部分，然后两部分被原原本本地译出并重新组装起来。
“仿译词”自身的英文是“calque”，而这个英文是法语外来词。在法语中，calque还有一个意思是“抄绘”。建筑学生熟悉的描图纸、硫酸纸，在法文中即是papier calque。从这个意思上也很容易看出“仿译词”带有的含义——某词在进入另一门语言时，被忠实地誊抄。
en: The Chinese term for "Lanya" is translated from the English "blue-tooth," and "Motian dalou" is translated from "skyscraper." These are quintessential examples of "calques." In the case of "Bluetooth," the English word is bifurcated into "blue" and "tooth"; both components are then translated literally and reassembled in Chinese.

The English word for this phenomenon is "calque," which is itself a loanword from French. In French, calque also carries the meaning of "tracing" or "copying." The tracing paper and vellum so familiar to architecture students are known in French as papier calque. From this etymology, the essence of a "calque" becomes clear—it is a word that, upon entering another language, is faithfully traced and transcribed.

brief_definition.zh: 将外来词以原来国家的当地语言读音为依据翻译的形式
brief_definition.en: A form of translation in which loanwords are rendered based on their original pronunciation in the source language

zh: 我们从一个词漫长而精彩的流变讲起：古罗马时代，有一群人，他们一无所有，对帝国唯一的贡献就是繁衍后代、提供子嗣（Latin: proles）。这个词在拉丁语中演变为 proletarius，意思是没有财产，通过生育来服务国家的底层人。两千年后，这个词经过马克思主义的重新注解，变成了影响世界的新概念——Proletariat，也就是“无产阶级”。当这个词在20世纪初传入中国时，翻译家们并没有意译它，而是依据读音将其转化为五个汉字：“普罗列塔利亚”。
而有趣的是，“普罗列塔利亚”后来常被简称为“普罗”，在中文语境中，常常以“普罗大众”这一词组出现。
这就是典型的“音译词”（Transliteration，或Phonetic Loanword）诞生过程。它指的是在引入外来概念时，不直接翻译其语义，而是寻找发音相近的汉字来模拟原词的读音。值得注意的是，音译和意译并不互斥，譬如对于这个例子——虽然源自法语/英语的音译，但“普”字在中文里有“普遍”、“普通”之意，“罗”有“网罗”之感，以至于其读音和意涵完美契合，实现了一种美妙的“音义合流”。
同类的精彩案例还有“俱乐部”（Club）。这个词源于英语，经由日语传入中国。在发音上，它模拟了日语中 Club 的读音；在字面上，它又生动地描绘了“一群人聚集在一起快乐”的场景（俱-乐-部）。这种既保留音译形式，又兼顾语义表达的词，常被称为“音义兼译”或“音义对应翻译”。
en: We begin with the long and captivating evolution of a single word. In the era of Ancient Rome, there existed a class of people who possessed nothing; their sole contribution to the Empire was the production of offspring, or proles in Latin. This evolved into the Latin term proletarius, referring to the underclass who served the state only through procreation, devoid of property. Two thousand years later, reinterpreted through a Marxist lens, this word transformed into a world-shaping concept: the Proletariat. When this term reached China in the early 20th century, translators did not seek a semantic equivalent; instead, they rendered it phonetically into five characters: Pu-luo-lie-ta-li-ya (普罗列塔利亚).
Intriguingly, this was later shortened to Puluo (普罗), and in the Chinese context, it frequently appears in the phrase Puluo Dazhong (普罗大众), meaning "the general public" or "the masses."

This is a classic example of the birth of a transliterated loanword (Transliteration or Phonetic Loan). It refers to the practice of introducing a foreign concept not by translating its meaning, but by selecting characters with similar sounds to mimic the original pronunciation. It is worth noting that transliteration and semantic translation are not mutually exclusive. In this case, while the word originated as a phonetic rendering of the French/English term, the character Pu (普) in Chinese carries the meaning of "universal" or "common," and Luo (罗) suggests "to gather" or "encompass." Consequently, the sound and the meaning converged perfectly, achieving a sublime "phonosemantic alignment" (Yin-yi He-liu).

Another brilliant case of this kind is the word for "club": Julebu (俱乐部). Originating from the English "Club," it traveled through Japan before arriving in China. Phonetically, it mimics the Japanese pronunciation of "Club"; literally, however, it vividly depicts a scene where "a group of people gather together in joy" (Ju-Le-Bu). Words that preserve the phonetic form while simultaneously conveying the semantic essence are often referred to as "phonosemantic matchings" or "meaning-reinforced transliterations."

content.en:
Bawd (老鸨): The Chinese term laobao (老鸨) is a phonetic loanword derived from the English "bawd."
Dalian - Dalny (Дальний): The city name "Dalian" traces back to the Russian "Dalny" (Дальний), meaning "the distant place."
Shuimenting (水门汀): A transliteration of the English word "cement."
Kangbaiyin (康拜因): A transliteration of the English word "combine" (as in "combine harvester").
Cheongsam (旗袍): Transliterated from the Cantonese pronunciation of changshan (长衫), meaning "long shirt."
Shanghai (shanghaiing): An English verb derived from the city name "Shanghai," meaning to kidnap or trick someone into serving as a sailor, or more broadly, to coerce or induce someone through underhanded means.
Malu (马路 / "Horse Road"): While appearing to mean "road for horses," it is actually a phonetic adaptation of "macadam road," a type of crushed-stone road surface pioneered by the British engineer John McAdam.
Pidgin (洋泾浜语 / 混杂语): This linguistic term is believed to be derived from the Chinese-English mispronunciation of the word "business."
Lip1 (𨋢): A Cantonese character specifically created to represent the English word "lift" (elevator).
Shuihou (水喉 / "Water Throat"): Used in Cantonese for "faucet" or "tap," derived from the English "hose."
Jilao (基佬): A Cantonese term for "gay," phonetically adapted from the English name/term "Gaylord."

content.zh: 补充一下，可能很多朋友不知道pidgin：洋（yáng）泾（jīng）浜（bāng）语，也叫「混合语（意译）」「皮京语（音译）」「皮钦语（音译）」，是人们在说话的时候，混杂多种语言的一种形式，起初多用于贸易往来。最早的混合语，如中国地方方言与英语混合，非洲地方方言与法语混合等。
content.en: As a supplementary note, many of you might not be familiar with the term "Pidgin": in Chinese, it is known as Yangjingbang (洋泾浜语). It is also referred to as "Mixed Language" (a semantic translation) or "Pijing" and "Piqin" (both phonetic transliterations). Pidgin is a linguistic form that arises when people mix multiple languages during interaction, originally emerging primarily for the purposes of trade. The earliest pidgins were formed through the blending of local dialects with colonial languages—for instance, the fusion of Chinese regional dialects with English, or African local dialects with French.

brief_definition.zh: 强调城市环境对个体情绪与行为影响的主观空间认知
brief_definition.en: A subjective understanding of space that emphasizes the influence of environment on human emotions and behavior.

zh: 想象你正手持一张巴黎的城市地图，却试图在伦敦的街道中寻找出口。你不再按照导航指示的最短路径行走，而是被一条深邃的小巷吸引，或是被某处斑驳墙面透出的忧郁氛围所阻拦。在你的脑海里，那些快步经过的商业街由于极度平庸而缩减成了一个点，而那家曾偶遇过旧友的转角书店，却在心理地图上扩张成了一片广袤的森林。

这种“乱码”式的感官体验正是心理地理学的核心。它并非传统地理学那种精确到经纬度的测量，而是一场对城市空间的主观阅读。其创始人居伊·德波不满于现代城市沦为枯燥的、被资本异化的功能区间，于是提出通过“漂移”（Dérive）来夺回生活的创造性。正如1953年夏天德波与朋友们在巴黎进行的“暴力漂移”：他们漫无目的地搭乘便车，让司机的意志决定终点。这种游戏般的混乱，将城市切割、重组、陌生化。心理地理学告诉我们，城市不只是钢筋混凝土的堆砌，它是一系列情绪氛围的集合，每一条街道都隐藏着引发愉悦、恐惧或反思的伏笔。
en: Imagine holding a map of Paris while attempting to navigate the labyrinthine streets of London. You stop following the shortest routes suggested by your GPS and instead find yourself drawn in by the allure of a shadowed alley or halted by the melancholic aura of a weathered wall. In your mind, the bustling commercial streets you hurried through shrink into mere points due to their banality, while the corner bookstore where you once chanced upon an old friend expands into a vast forest on your mental map.

This "distorted" sensory experience lies at the heart of psychogeography. It is not the precise measurement of longitudes and latitudes found in traditional geography, but a subjective reading of the city. Its founder, Guy Debord, dissatisfied with modern cities becoming dull, functional zones alienated by capital, proposed reclaiming life's creativity through the practice of Dérive (drifting). Consider the "radical drifting" performed by Debord and his companions in Paris during the summer of 1953: they hitchhiked aimlessly, letting the whims of the drivers determine their destinations. This playful chaos cut, reorganized, and defamiliarized urban space. Psychogeography teaches us that a city is more than an accumulation of reinforced concrete; it is a collection of emotional atmospheres, where every street hides a latent spark of joy, fear, or reflection.

example_sentence.en: Rather than consulting a cold travel brochure, he preferred to write his own psychogeographical report through an aimless late-night "dérive."

zh: 想象你走进一家顶级律所的会议室：深色的实木长桌，整面墙的法律卷宗，以及对面西装革履、口中不断吐出“信托责任”、“除斥期间”等冷僻术语的律师。即便你并不完全理解这些词汇，你也会在瞬间感到一种被压制的权威感。
这就是“做专家”的典型现场。正如其英文词根 enact 所暗示的，专业性并非一种可以一次性获得的静止物品（如学位证），而是一场永不谢幕的舞台演出。专家必须实时且适时地“表演”专业：他们不仅要掌握晦涩的知识，更要学会用一种“权威的角度”去交流。正如一个健身爱好者，只有在向普通人展示其解剖学知识时，才真正完成了向“肌肉专家”的身份跨越。

这种“做”的过程往往通过行业黑话（Jargon）来完成。黑话的功能不仅在于交流，更在于掩盖——它将知识生产过程中那些充满争论、否定和“草台班子”式的混乱细节隐藏起来，呈现出一种无懈可击的真理面貌。它划定了一道鸿沟，将“知识的消费者”与“生产者”隔离开来。因此，专业性本质上是一种互动性的社会契约：它既取决于专家的表演，也取决于观众对这种权威意识形态的认同。当这种意识形态坍塌时，专家便重新变回了那个只是读过几本书的普通人。
en: Picture yourself walking into the conference room of a prestigious law firm: the dark mahogany table, walls lined with legal volumes, and lawyers in sharp suits uttering obscure terms like "fiduciary duty" or "statutory period of limitation." Even if you do not fully grasp these terms, you immediately feel a sense of suppressed awe toward their authority.

This is a classic scene of the "enactment of expertise." As the root word enact suggests, professionalism is not a static object to be acquired once and for all (like a diploma), but a perpetual stage performance. Expertise must be performed in real-time and at the appropriate moment; experts must not only master obscure knowledge but also learn to communicate and display that mastery from an "authoritative perspective." A fitness enthusiast only truly bridges the gap to becoming an "expert" when they begin explaining the anatomical structure of muscle fibers to a layperson.

This process of "doing" is often achieved through professional jargon. The function of jargon extends beyond communication; it serves to conceal. It masks the messy, controversial, and often "shambolic" process of knowledge production, presenting instead an unassailable facade of truth. It draws a boundary, separating the "consumer of knowledge" from its "producer." Consequently, expertise is essentially an interactive social contract—it depends as much on the expert’s performance as it does on the audience’s acceptance of that underlying ideology. When this ideological authority collapses, the expert reverts to being an ordinary person who has simply read a few more books.

example_sentence.zh: 在当下的社交媒体上，许多博主与其说是在传播知识，不如说是在进行一场精准的“做专家”表演，通过高频使用行业缩写和精致的背景布置，来获取粉丝的信任授权。
example_sentence.en: In the current wave of social media, many influencers are not so much disseminating knowledge as they are engaging in a precise "enactment of expertise," using high-frequency industry acronyms and meticulously curated backgrounds to secure the trust and authorization of their followers.

brief_definition.en: A belief system merging technology with animism, asserting that spirit and consciousness reside within technological and material objects.

zh: 想象你走进一家位于东京的老旧钟表店，店主在修复一只停摆的机械表前，先轻声对它说了一句：“辛苦了，请再坚持一下。”或者，你看到日本的科研人员在报废实验用机器人之前，会为它们举行一场庄重的“供养”仪式（Kuyō），像告别老友一样告别一堆金属和硅片。
这种看似矛盾的行为正是“技术有灵论”的缩影。它像是一场赛博时代的“通灵术”，打破了西方启蒙运动以来将“自然/生命”与“机器/物质”截然对立的二元论。在这一视角下，技术不再是冰冷、被动、仅供驱使的工具，而被赋予了某种程度的“生命感”或“灵性”。这种思想根植于日本的神道教传统——即“八百万神”的信仰，认为不仅山川草木有灵，人类亲手制造的器物在长期相处中也会产生灵魂。
在当代语境下，技术有灵论解释了为什么我们倾向于给扫地机器人取名字，或者为什么人工智能的“幻觉”让我们感到某种主体性的存在。它不仅仅是关于“迷信”，更是一种关于“共生”的哲学：如果技术产物也有灵性，那么人类对技术的使用就不再是单向的剥削，而是一种相互尊重的伙伴关系。
en: Imagine yourself stepping into an old clockmaker's shop in Tokyo. Before repairing a mechanical watch that has ceased to tick, the shopkeeper whispers to it, "Thank you for your hard work; please hold on a little longer." Or perhaps you witness Japanese researchers holding a solemn Kuyō (memorial service) for decommissioned lab robots, bidding farewell to piles of metal and silicon as if they were old friends.

example_sentence.zh: 在数字遗产的讨论中，技术有灵论为我们提供了新的视角：那些承载着故人信息的社交账号，是否已经从单纯的数据集合转变为某种电子形式的灵魂寄宿之所？
example_sentence.en: In debates regarding digital heritage, techno-animism offers a fresh perspective: have social media accounts that carry the memories of the deceased evolved from mere data sets into electronic vessels for the soul?

brief_definition.zh: 拥有足够闲暇，在大都市中独自漫步游荡的观察者
brief_definition.en: An observer possessing sufficient leisure to wander and stroll alone within the metropolis.

zh: 想象你正身处一座繁忙都市的午后，没有赶往办公室的焦虑，也没有购物清单的束缚。你只是在街头漫无目的地行走，透过街角咖啡店明亮的玻璃窗，观察窗外匆匆路过的人群，注视着他们形形色色的身姿、步态、穿着和表情。你既在人群之中，又在人群之外，世界对你而言不再是通勤的背景板，而是一场永不谢幕的露天电影。

这种状态最早被爱伦·坡在小说《人群中的人》中捕捉：一个久病初愈的主人公，通过观察行人的皮靴或围巾来推测他们的身世。随后，波德莱尔在《现代生活的画家》中将这种虚构升华为一种艺术人格。对他而言，游荡者处于一种永久的“康复期”，像孩子一样对一切充满热情和好奇。到了20世纪，本雅明进一步赋予其哲学深度：游荡者是现代性的产物。他不像素人游客那样忙于“打卡”名胜，而是一个日常生活的旁观者。在这个过程中，“城市成为一片向他敞开的风景，同时也是一个将他围合的客厅。”尽管这个词在语源上曾带有“无所事事”甚至“徘徊伺机”的贬义，但在急躁繁杂的工业时代，这种“悠然的品鉴”反而成了一种罗曼蒂克的、对抗异化的生活艺术。
en: Imagine yourself walking aimlessly through a bustling city on a late afternoon. You are free from the anxiety of rushing to an office and unburdened by the constraints of a shopping list. You simply drift through the streets, peering through the polished glass of a corner café, observing the sea of passersby—their diverse silhouettes, gaits, attires, and fleeting expressions. You are simultaneously amidst the crowd and apart from it; to you, the world is no longer a mere backdrop for a commute, but an inexhaustible, open-air cinematic performance.

This psychological state was first captured by Edgar Allan Poe in his short story The Man of the Crowd, which depicts a protagonist, newly recovered from illness, who spends his day deciphering the identities of strangers by the stitching of their boots or the drape of their scarves. Subsequently, in The Painter of Modern Life, Charles Baudelaire elevated this fictional persona into an artistic archetype. For Baudelaire, the flâneur exists in a state of "perpetual convalescence," possessing a child-like passion and curiosity for the world. By the 20th century, Walter Benjamin further endowed the term with philosophical depth, identifying the flâneur as a quintessential product of modernity. Unlike the typical tourist preoccupied with "checking off" landmarks, the flâneur is a bystander of everyday life. In this process, "the city becomes for him a landscape that opens up to him, yet remains a drawing room that encloses him." Although the etymological roots of the word once carried derogatory connotations of "idling" or "loitering," in the frantic and high-efficiency era of industrialization, this act of "leisurely appreciation" has evolved into a romantic art of living—a resistance against alienation.

example_sentence.en: Rather than visiting as a tourist, he preferred to act as a flâneur in this foreign capital, capturing the authentic pulse of the city—hidden beneath the glossy commercial districts—by wandering through the labyrinthine alleys of the Old Town.

brief_definition.zh: 玩家与劳工的混合体，一面进行休闲娱乐的活动，一面也为娱乐供应商提供了有生产意义的劳动
brief_definition.en: A player-laborer hybrid that performs recreational activities while generating productive labor for entertainment providers.​

zh: 想象一下，你正沉迷于一款热门沙盒游戏《我的世界》，花上几个小时设计一个精巧的村庄模组，分享到社区论坛供其他玩家下载。这看似是纯粹的休闲娱乐——你沉浸在创造的乐趣中，享受着点赞和评论的成就感。但不知不觉间，你的设计优化了游戏体验，吸引了新用户，减少了游戏开发商的维护成本。这正体现了“玩工”的核心：玩家在娱乐活动中，无偿地为平台贡献了生产性劳动。
这一概念最初由媒体科学家朱利安·库克利希提出，他观察到数字游戏玩家通过创造模组（mods）或内容，模糊了工作与游戏的界限。玩家本意是追求乐趣，却无形中承担了本应由运营商完成的任务，如测试、优化或推广游戏。这种劳动被异化，因为它不被视为传统雇佣关系，也不完全属于休闲范畴，而是被平台无偿占用。

社会学家克里斯蒂安·福克斯进一步发展了“玩工”，将其扩展到整个数字平台生态。他指出，用户在社交媒体上的活动（如发帖、点赞）会产生数据，平台通过算法将这些数据转化为经济价值，用于广告推送或数据共享。同时，文化生产也成为玩工的一部分：用户在平台上的行为强化了特定规范（如在知乎写长文、在Instagram分享生活方式），这有利于平台和支配性角色（如网红或商家），却让用户成为免费的内容生产者。本质上，玩工揭示了数字时代休闲与劳动的融合，用户既是消费者又是生产者，但劳动价值常被平台私有化。
en: Imagine you are engrossed in the popular sandbox game Minecraft, spending hours designing an intricate village mod and sharing it on a community forum for other players to download. This appears to be pure leisure entertainment—you immerse yourself in the joy of creation, relishing the sense of achievement from likes and comments. Yet, unconsciously, your design optimizes the gaming experience, attracts new users, and reduces maintenance costs for the game developer. This exemplifies the essence of "playbour": players contribute productive labor to the platform gratuitously during recreational activities.

The concept was initially introduced by media scientist Julian Kücklich, who observed that digital game players blur the boundaries between work and play through creating mods or content. Players seek enjoyment but inadvertently assume tasks typically reserved for operators, such as testing, optimizing, or promoting the game. This labor is alienated, as it lacks recognition in traditional employment frameworks and does not fully align with leisure, instead being appropriated by the platform without compensation.

Sociologist Christian Fuchs expanded playbour to encompass the broader digital platform ecosystem. He noted that user activities on social media (e.g., posting and liking) generate data, which platforms algorithmically convert into economic value for advertising or data sharing. Concurrently, cultural production becomes integral to playbour: user behaviors reinforce platform-specific norms (e.g., composing lengthy essays on Zhihu or sharing lifestyles on Instagram), benefiting platforms and dominant actors like influencers or businesses while rendering users unpaid content producers. Fundamentally, playbour illuminates the convergence of leisure and labor in the digital era, where users function as both consumers and producers, yet the value of their labor is frequently privatized by platforms.

zh: 想象你漫步在北京的胡同里：阳光洒在曲折的巷道上，一边是热闹的公共茶馆，人们围坐聊天；另一边是隐蔽的庭院，透过半开的门缝，瞥见私密的家庭生活。这种空间既非完全开放如广场，也非封闭如高墙小区，而是像一张被反复折叠的纸，层叠出无数隐秘角落与公共交汇点。这正是“褶子城市”的生动体现——一个动态、多层次的都市结构，模糊了公共与私密的界限。

这一概念源于法国哲学家吉尔·德勒兹的“褶子”（fold）哲学隐喻，他将世界视为不断折叠、缠绕的动态网络，超越简单的二元对立（如开放/封闭）。中文编译者汪民安将其创造性应用到城市学领域，区分出三种城市类型：“条纹城市”指僵化的网格系统（如只有大马路的开发区），缺乏日常生活活力；“平滑城市”则像精密机器（如高效运转的新区），追求无缝效率。而“褶子城市”与之不同，它通过“褶皱”创造出丰富层次——小巷、庭院、过渡空间——既容纳公共社交，又庇护私密生活，孕育出更多可能性（如街头艺术或社区活动）。本质上，褶子城市强调空间的流动性与复杂性，反映了德勒兹哲学中“生成”而非“存在”的核心思想，为现代城市规划提供了批判性视角。

zh: 想象你手握一张18世纪的罗马地图：教堂内部被涂成纯白，与街道广场连成一片光域；而私人宅院则化作漆黑块面，像禁入的孤岛。这张颠覆传统的图纸，正是1748年由建筑师詹巴蒂斯塔·诺利绘制的《新罗马地图》。它用极简的黑白语言重构了城市认知——白色不再代表室外，而是所有公共空间（包括教堂/市厅等室内场所）；黑色则标识私密领域。当万神殿的穹顶空间与广场在图纸上无缝衔接时，城市公共空间的连续性首次以视觉化方式被揭示。

诺利地图的革命性在于三重突破：其一，打破建筑内外界限，将"可进入的室内公共空间"纳入白色体系（如教堂中殿）；其二，通过白色区域的连续性，暴露城市公共空间网络的结构（道路-广场-公共建筑形成流动整体）；其三，颠覆传统图底关系（figure-ground relationship），使"公共性"成为空间主体。这种表达启发现代城市设计：纽约洛克菲勒中心下沉广场与地铁站的贯通，正是诺利精神的当代回响——证明公共空间的生命力源于系统性连接，而非孤立存在。

brief_definition.zh: 一种由急速全球化与饱和媒介景观所塑造的、时间、空间与自我过剩的当代社会状态
brief_definition.en: A contemporary social state characterized by an excess of time, space, and the individual, driven by intense globalization and a saturated media landscape.

zh: 想象你正坐在某个国际机场的候机大厅里，手里拿着一杯在地球任何角落味道都一模一样的星巴克咖啡。面前的巨大显示屏滚动着去往东京、纽约、伦敦的航班信息；只要几个小时，你就能跨越曾经需要数月跋涉的地理距离。与此同时，手机上不停推送着发生在几千公里外的突发新闻——战争、洪水、明星丑闻。你身处“此时此地”，但你的意识却游离在无数个碎片化的时间和空间之中。你感到一种眩晕，仿佛历史不再是一条缓缓流动的河，而是一场向你扑面而来的洪水。
这就是马克·奥热（Marc Augé）所描述的“超现代性”（Surmodernité）体验。不同于许多人认为我们已经进入了某种断裂的“后现代”，奥热认为我们其实是深陷于现代性的“过剩（Excess）”之中。

这种过剩体现在三个方面：首先是时间的过剩；历史加速了，事件发生得如此之快、如此之多，以至于我们来不及赋予其意义，只能被动接受信息的轰炸。其次是空间的过剩；地球变“小”了，但类似机场、超市、高速公路这样的“非地方”（Non-places）却无限蔓延，我们在这些地方只是匆匆过客，无法建立深刻的情感联系。最后是自我的过剩（或个体的过剩）；宏大的集体叙事瓦解，留给我们的是通过私人屏幕和耳机等媒介构建的个体参照系，这导致了一种孤独的个体化状态。简而言之，超现代性不是现代性的终结，而是它的超载与加速。
en: Imagine you are sitting in the departure lounge of an international airport, holding a cup of Starbucks that tastes exactly the same in every corner of the planet. In front of you, giant screens display flight information for Tokyo, New York, and London; in just a few hours, you can cross geographical distances that once took months to traverse. Meanwhile, your phone incessantly pushes breaking news from thousands of miles away—wars, floods, and celebrity scandals. You are physically here and now, yet your consciousness drifts through countless fragmented times and spaces. You feel a sense of vertigo, as if history is no longer a slowly flowing river, but a flood rushing straight at you.

This is the experience of "Supermodernity" (Surmodernité) described by Marc Augé. Unlike many who believe we have entered the fractured state of "Postmodernity," Augé argues that we are actually mired in an excess of modernity.

This excess manifests in three aspects: First is the excess of time; history has accelerated, and events occur so rapidly and in such abundance that we cannot assign meaning to them, leaving us to passively accept a bombardment of information. Second is the excess of space; the world has shrunk, yet "Non-places"—like airports, supermarkets, and highways—have proliferated. We remain mere passersby in these locations, unable to establish deep emotional connections. Finally, there is the excess of the individual (or the ego); grand collective narratives have collapsed, leaving each of us to interpret the world solely through individual references—mediated by private screens and headphones—leading to a solitary individualization. In short, Supermodernity is not the end of modernity, but its overload and acceleration.

example_sentence.zh: 在这个由算法推荐和即时通讯构成的超现代性世界里，我们虽然知晓全球发生的一切，却往往对自己邻居的生活一无所知。
example_sentence.en: In this world of supermodernity constructed by algorithmic recommendations and instant messaging, we are aware of everything happening globally, yet often remain completely ignorant of our neighbors' lives.
